utterances: There is in the - at least the run up to the election and right after it, it was energetic.
It was exciting.
The possibility was exciting.
Now, everytime you turn on the news, it is really depressing.
Myself, I've had to back away from cable news because I was just getting overwhelmed with the dire financial situation in our country.
Casey, do you think that that's part of it?
That people are just having news fatigue, and you have people like the popular health expert Dr. Andrew Weil saying, take a break from the news for your health.
Well, yeah.
Well, you know, people have been hearing about this big event that's going to be coming up, the election.
So, it's a lot like the NFL and the Super Bowl.
After the game is over, people lose interest in the NFL until the season starts up again.
But there was that one big event that people are waiting for, so we shouldn't be surprised.
Same thing.
Eggnog consumption is probably down in the last two weeks, you know.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know, these things happen.
Speak for yourself.
I've got it in an ice cube truck.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, but I mean, Jay, ultimately, for you guys who were all active bloggers, I mean, there are some very personal decisions that you get to make, and Carmen was giving good news about her traffic.
Do you have a sense of whether or not the people who read and visit your blog are - they're wanting the hard news or the political news.
Do you have any sense of the opinions of people on what they want?
I'm in the same, you know, boat as Carmen.
My blog is not a political blog.
I talk politics because, obviously, I mean, that's what a lot of people want to talk about, but, you know, just like Carmen, my site traffic is actually going up since November.
I think people had (unintelligible), you know, people were fatigued.
They're tired.
I mean, it's almost like - I don't know first hand.
I'm just judging on what my wife told me.
After you carry the baby for nine months, the last thing you want to do is carry a baby for nine months.
And, you know, this (unintelligible) political season was just like that.
It was more than being political, I think this year was almost like a reality show.
You had so many personalities.
You have Sarah Palin.
You had, you know, Joe the plumber.
You had Barack Obama and all the historical significance there.
I mean, it's almost like watching the last 11 months or so of political coverage, it hasn't really been politics.

So, a lot of the people who got themselves ramped up and who were interested in this all of the sudden, you know, they're not going to be as interested in the soup and bolts and the day-to-day, you know, goings on now that Obama is in office, and he's appointing the cabinet.
I mean, those are less sexy...
Almost in office.
Almost in office.
I'm sorry.
Those are a little less sexy and less interesting, you know, aspects of the whole political process, and most people, you know, they jump ship.
They were interested in all the theater, and now, that's over.

And again, I think, again, like Carmen said, if you're a blogger, and you've got interesting enough material - on my site, you know, I've switched now to doing a lot more sports, a lot more pop culture, you know, a lot of the things, again, that don't depend on, you know, the political machine, and my site traffic has continued to go up.
Well, I want to transition into one of those points where politics and pop culture meet, and that is the inauguration.
You've got now NBA stars, foreign dignitaries, and, of course, everyone from the hood showing up in Washington, D.C.
or at least planning to.
And a lot of people have been saying, what can I actually go to, whether or not I'm in D.C.
So, there was an announcement that there would be a neighborhood inaugural ball that was actually hosted by or official with the president.
Because there are balls that are - you know, the official balls, where he's definitely going to go around and visit.
And then, there's ones, there's a zillion other parties.
But an official ball has a very specific status, and this one is going to be at the Washington Convention Center.

There's going to be tickets put aside for local residents, but there's also going to be webcasting and texting and all of these, you know, so many people were going to be having house parties or there's going to be street corner parties.
Washington, D.C.
delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton recently told NPR she's excited about her new neighbors and just all of the energy that this whole season is bringing.
They spoke about reaching out to the district from the beginning.

We're very pleased, of course, because we've not had a president who felt quite at home here as Barack Obama, but that's because he is one of the - in fact, he is the first big-city president in memory.
Of course, her neighbors are now the Obamas.
Their kids started in school.
Carmen, what do you think, just quickly, about the idea of trying to make the official process of the inauguration festivities open to more people?
Is that a good idea?
Give me a sense of what one of your days is like when you talk about doing better music, creating better music, what do you do after you wake up in the morning?
Well, usually, I'm trying to make peace with my neighbors.
I love the idea.
I have no idea logistically how that's going to work.
I looked - I've read everything, and I'm a former producer, and I look at the logistics.
I don't understand it.
It's above my pay grade.
I'll be there blogging it for AOL Black Voices, but I don't know how they're going to make it work.
Well, I mean, you know, Casey, do you think it's one of these things where maybe you might be better off sitting in your house with your computer?
Look, I'll tell you.
I'm getting out of town for another week.
You know, e-mail me if you need a place to stay because I'm going to be - yes.
Uh huh.
Don't say that.
Uh huh.
Everyone who you went to elementary school is now dialing your phone number.
Hey, go ahead.
E-mail me.
E-mail me.
It already happened, right?
I know other people who have places trying to rent out.
That's the only - I'm not interested.
I'm going to be out of town.
Jay, what do you think?
I mean, is this going to be a situation where no matter what good will goes into planning, things are going to be a little messy?
I agree.
I mean, logistically speaking, you have no idea how to prepare for this sort of thing.
Personally, I think a lot of people are going to come here and be disappointed.
I think so many people coming from out of town think this is going to be easy to get in and around.
But I think, logistically, Metro has no idea what they're going to, you know, be dealing with.
Personally, I'm going to be there for it.
You know, our plan is just to go in and take a train and get as close to the festivities as we can.
As soon as the inauguration and the swearing in is over, we're out of here because again, it's going to be a zoo.
A lot of people, like Casey was saying, you know, are getting out of town.
Oh, yeah.
I've seen now a trend with or I've heard a lot of people now talking about swapping homes with other people.

You know, like for example, I'll go to Florida, and I'll take your home, and you can take my house here, you know, for the week at the election - I mean, I'm sorry, for the inauguration, so really interesting time.
Well, in that case, if anybody in Hawaii is listening to me, you should e-mail me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Same here.
I think the Obama family might be on vacation.
I'll take their place - $9 million or whatever.
I'll take it.
Yeah.
All right, on that note, guys, thanks so much, and if you're going to the inauguration, enjoy it.
And if you're not going, enjoy it.
OK.
Later.
Thank you.
We're speaking with Jay Anderson of Average Bro, Casey Lartigue, whose blog is the Casey Lartigue Show.
Both were at our headquarters in Washington.
We've also got media consultant Carmen Dixon, who writes the blog All About Race and blogs for AOL Black Voices.
She'll be at the inauguration.
And she was with me today at NPR West.
You can find links to their blogs on ours at nprnewsandnotes.org.
And the conversation doesn't stop here.
Be sure and visit us online at nprnewsandviews.org and upload your pictures if you are celebrating next week.
Fifty years ago today, a lanky college student from Oregon won the high jump at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics and revolutionized his sport.
NPR's Tom Goldman tells us the story of the Fosbury Flop.
For a man who professes to live in the moment, Dick Fosbury has spent this week deep inside the past on a tour commemorating the day he confounded the sports world.
